awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Nonlinear Operation of Nanoelectromechanical Systems (NEMS)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will address open scientific questions in nanotechnology leading to improved nano-scale sensors. The project will promote the progress of science and advance the national health, prosperity and security by enabling ultra-sensitive and robust nanoelectromechanical devices. Nanoelectromechanical sensors can easily detect single atoms and molecules, and are expected to provide powerful new approaches to medical diagnostics and environmental monitoring potentially with single-molecule sensitivity. This research project will vastly expand the operational parameters of nanoelectromechanical sensors and enable them to operate robustly in the nonlinear regime. The machinery and methods developed in this project will allow for widespread use of these microscopic machines and facilitate rapid progress toward the various sensing applications. The project will also contribute to U.S. workforce development by significantly enhancing undergraduate education at Gordon College, a small liberal arts institution. 

The overarching goals of this project are to resolve scientific questions pertinent to nonlinear operation of nanoelectromechanical resonators and to develop a toolkit for operating them. So far, nanoelectromechanical resonators have mostly been operated in the linear regime. In the linear regime, the widely-used resonance tracking techniques work by locking onto the rapidly-changing but smooth phase or amplitude response of a resonator around its mechanical resonance. However, such feedback techniques do not work in the nonlinear regime, because physical observables have discontinuous jumps due to bifurcations. Instead of focusing on complex control algorithms and controllers, this project will systematically investigate the possibility of finding novel physical observables, which may allow for controlling nonlinear resonators using standard controllers. In order to validate this project's approach, the team will develop a host of novel experimental techniques and instruments by combining nanoelectromechanical resonators with Field Programmable Gated Array (FPGA) electronics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching aim of this project was to study the fundamental dynamics of artificial nanometer-scale structures. The nanometer-scale structures used in this work are called nano-electro-mechanical Systems (NEMS), which are, in essence, tiny guitar strings and vibrate when “plucked.” These strings, however, are a factor of 10,000 smaller and vibrate at a pitch 10,000 times higher as compared to a guitar string. If these nano-strings are plucked with large forces, they vibrate at large amplitudes and exhibit complex behavior. This limit is termed nonlinear dynamics because the vibrational amplitude is no longer simply proportional to the force in this limit. The overarching goal of the project was to study the fundamental aspects of how these tiny devices became nonlinear.

In the first phase of the project, we created new engineering tools to enable our fundamental studies. In particular, we designed and fabricated nano-strings using semiconductor processes, characterized the properties of these nano-strings and developed computational tools to predict their behaviors. We also developed flexible and programmable hardware to better interact with these tiny devices. In the ensuing experiments, we explored the source of nonlinearity and how the nonlinearity emerged in the higher vibrational modes of the nanostrings. We determined that the source of the nonlinearity was stretching of the nanostring as its vibrational amplitude become larger and larger. We also observed that as one went to higher vibration modes, one measure of nonlinearity—the Duffing constant—increased dramatically. At the same time, the amplitude of the vibration needed to trigger this unusual behavior became smaller. We measured the range over which the device behaved linearly (called its linear dynamic range, or LDR) and found that it growed only slightly as one employed higher modes.

The project provided support for the Ph.D. studies of two students. Several undergraduate students participated in the research and got hands-on training in nanoscience and nanotechnology. The material from the project enhanced the curricula of undergraduate and graduate courses, exposing the students to fundamentals of vibrations, nanoscience, and nanotechnology. The NEMS devices developed here could one day be used for sensing, communications , and computing in unforeseen new applications.
